awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Combining Models and Experiment for Quantitative Characterization of Electrocatalytic Carbon Dioxide Reduction on Doped Ceria
awd_abstract_narration:
The project investigates a high-temperature electrochemical approach for converting the carbon in carbon dioxide (CO2) gas to higher value carbon-containing products such as hydrocarbon fuels, thereby serving as a critical component in eventual closed carbon-cycle processes for renewable energy generation.  Specifically, the project will investigate the reduction of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide (CO) on high-temperature cerium oxide based electrodes utilizing a combination of experimental techniques, theoretical models, and statistical methods to distinguish between various reaction mechanisms that have been proposed but remain unverified.  The resulting understanding will provide guidance for designing solid oxide electrodes with improved efficiency and durability.

Thin-film test cells with ceria working electrodes on yttria-stabilized zirconia (YSZ) electrolytes will be fabricated, exposed to CO and CO2-containing gases and polarized at high temperature.  The potential gradient in the film caused by the polarization yields a gradient in the surface potential as a function of distance from the current collector. These changes in surface potential - a quantity closely related to the concentrations of active intermediates on the ceria surface - will be measured, during cell operation, with sub-100 nm lateral resolution utilizing in-operando high-temperature scanning surface potential microscopy (HT-SSPM). These data, along with full-cell electrochemical impedance spectroscopy data (EIS), will be collected for a matrix of different experimental conditions including changes in gas composition, temperature, applied cell potential, dopant concentration, and thermal aging.  Electrocatalytic phase-field modeling (EPFM), which couples mechanistic models of the catalytic reaction with the material behavior of the ceria electrode, will be quantitatively calibrated to the entire experimental dataset using Bayesian model-based analysis (BMA). Models generated and conclusions drawn during the course of this project will be useful for further development of high-temperature, mixed ionic-electronic conducting catalysts. The unique coupling of state-of-the-art in-operando HT-SSPM and EPFM methods is made possible by Bayesian calibration, which quantitatively links large experimental datasets and complex models, leading to estimates of model parameters (with uncertainty quantification) along with assessments of the model fitness in light of the data.  BMA also affords the opportunity to incorporate existing measurements or calculations (including quantum calculations) of key parameters in the analysis.  In addition to the technical elements, the project will include a lab activity for high school physics students that will be developed in the researchers' local communities and publicized nationally.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Solar fuels combine power derived from the sun and carbon dioxide captured from the air to create hydrocarbon-based fuels such as jet fuel (kerosene), diesel and gasoline. A critical step in this multi-step process is the conversion of carbon dioxide to carbon monoxide and oxygen. One of the most promising routes for this process is electrocatalysis, in which electricity (generated from renewable sources) provides the energy for the molecular splitting. Low temperature processes usually rely on copper electrodes and carbon dioxide dissolved in water. High temperature processes are potentially more efficient, but have not been studied as closely.

Cerium dioxide (also called "ceria") is one of the world's most important catalysts. Ceria is unique in its ability to 'breathe' oxygen -- that is, releasing it at higher temperatures and taking it in at lower temperatures. Applying electrical energy also activates this breathing process. When thermal or electrical energy forces oxygen out of the ceria structure, it creates a strong driving force for re-incorporation of oxygen from any source, including from carbon dioxide. This route for carbon dioxide splitting in which oxygen vacancies provide the catalytically 'active site' is the subject of significant scientific investigation.

Often scientific models of catalytic surfaces based on fundamental physics and chemistry miss important effects taking place below the surface. This is because theories of electrified surfaces and interfaces have not kept up with evidence on the relationship between the surface of the material and its bulk state now available from microscopic-level experiments such as electron microscopy. The PI and collaborators developed a modern approach for modeling these subsurface effects.

In this project, the team to applied this new model to ceria surfaces in the process of electrocatalytic CO2 conversion, combining theory and experiment in order to estimate model parameters. The quantified models and related datasets will soon be released to the public as open-source software. In the process, unprecedented methods for combining nanometer-scale models with microscopic experiments were demonstrated. In the course of the project the model and its various applications to surfaces and interfaces in ceria have been recognized by the scientific community. Soon the community will have access to tools that implement the new models, using an open-source software framework developed and maintained at Idaho National Laboratory (the MOOSE framework).

In addition to the models and datasets soon to be released, the project has yielded two articles published in peer-reviewed journals so far, with two more in preparation. A Ph.D. student and multiple undergraduate students have been supported. This project was also instrumental in establishing the PI in his scientific community.


Last Modified: 11/22/2023
Modified by: David S Mebane
